dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey everyone, welcome back to the show! Today, we're digging into something shiny and, uh, super valuable: global gold reserves.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey everyone, welcome back to the show! Today, we're digging into something shiny and, uh, super valuable: global gold reserves.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Ooh, I like shiny! So, who's got the biggest pile of, like, the yellow stuff?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ooh, I like shiny! So, who's got the biggest pile of, like, the yellow stuff?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, no surprise here, the United States is still number one, by a long shot. They actually added over 92 tons recently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, no surprise here, the United States is still number one, by a long shot. They actually added over ninety two tons recently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The United States which holds the highest reserves globally, added 92.23 tons, increasing its haul to 9,057.38 tons from 8,965.15 tons.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, 92 tons? That's a massive haul! What about, uh, the rest of the top contenders?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, ninety two tons? That's a massive haul! What about, uh, the rest of the top contenders?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Germany's solidly in second place, still holding over 3,700 tons. And then the IMF, the International Monetary Fund, they're sitting on a huge chunk too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Germany's solidly in second place, still holding over three thousand, seven hundred tons. And then the I M F, the International Monetary Fund, they're sitting on a huge chunk too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Germany is second with 3,703.74 tons of Gold... The International Monetary Fund holds 3,100.38 tons in gold reserves...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, the IMF. So, are most countries, like, adding to their gold stash or are some, um, selling off?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, the I M F. So, are most countries, like, adding to their gold stash or are some, um, selling off?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's a mixed bag, actually, but mostly an increase. China, for instance, upped theirs by nearly 37 tons. India, Japan, Switzerland all gained.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a mixed bag, actually, but mostly an increase. China, for instance, upped theirs by nearly thirty seven tons. India, Japan, Switzerland all gained.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: China has upped its reserves by 36.75 tons... India has gained 13.85 tons in Gold... Switzerland has liquidated about 0.83 tons... Japan currently sits on 841.46 tons in gold reserves after liquidating 1.52 tons.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] So, a lot of accumulation then. But I heard some, uh, countries actually reduced their holdings?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, a lot of accumulation then. But I heard some, uh, countries actually reduced their holdings?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: You're right! Russia, for example, actually reduced theirs by over 65 tons. And the European Union also saw a slight reduction.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You're right! Russia, for example, actually reduced theirs by over sixty five tons. And the European Union also saw a slight reduction.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Russia holds 2,569.72 tons in gold reserves, an addition of 65.51 tons on the 2,504.21 tons held in March. The European Union liquidated 1.22 tons in Gold, reducing its reserve to 554.82 tons.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Interesting. So what's driving all this gold movement, especially, um, you know, recently?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Interesting. So what's driving all this gold movement, especially, um, you know, recently?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, researchers at Finbold.com pointed out that when the pandemic hit, there was this 'dash for gold.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, researchers at the Finbold link pointed out that when the pandemic hit, there was this dash for gold.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Finbold.com researchers commented on the gold purchasing trend during the pandemic. According to the researchers: When the pandemic hit, most countries began a new dash towards Gold.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A dash for gold? Why then?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Think about it: central banks were printing massive amounts of money to stimulate the global economy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Think about it: central banks were printing massive amounts of money to stimulate the global economy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The dash came in the backdrop of central banks printing massive amounts of money to stimulate the global economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, right. All that stimulus, uh, leading to inflation worries?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, right. All that stimulus, uh, leading to inflation worries?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Gold continues to have that intrinsic value. It's seen as a reliable safeguard against, like, heightened inflation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Gold continues to have that intrinsic value. It's seen as a reliable safeguard against, like, heightened inflation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Notably, Gold continues to have an intrinsic value reassuring countries of good returns in case of heightened inflation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, it's basically countries looking for a safe haven for their wealth when things get, um, uncertain.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it's basically countries looking for a safe haven for their wealth when things get, um, uncertain.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. An old, dependable asset in, you know, wild times.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. An old, dependable asset in, you know, wild times.
